newsitem.title: USA: Teamsters union begins strike at UPS.
newsitem.headline: Teamsters union begins strike at UPS.

text.p: The Teamsters union began a strike at United Parcel Service on Monday, hours after negotiators failed to agree on a new contract at the largest U.S. small package carrier.

Striking drivers, package-sorters and loaders shut down UPS facilities across the country in a labour dispute over pay, benefits and job security with the company that controls four-fifths of the U.S. package delivery business.
Earlier, Teamsters President Ron Carey said contract talks had broken down and there was no sense in continuing negotiations with a federal mediator and company officials.
"We have exhausted every possible approach to solve the problem," Carey told reporters as the union delegation left the talks just after 10 p.m. EDT (0200 GMT) on Sunday.

Chief UPS negotiator Dave Murray called the union's decision to abandon the talks "highly irresponsible" and said the union's leadership should let its members review the company's "last, best and final offer," made last week.
Immediately after the talks broke down, Labour Secretary Alexis Herman called on the two sides to go back to the bargaining table and avoid disruption to the public.
"UPS and Teamsters representatives should press on and not rest until they find the common ground that resolves this dispute with the least disruption," she said.
UPS handles 12 million packages a day and employs 301,000 people in the United States, 185,000 of whom are represented by the Teamsters.

"We're striking for every worker in America. We can't have only low service-industry wages in this country," said Randy Walls, a 47-year-old UPS tractor-trailer driver on nighttime picket duty in Atlanta.
The Independent Pilots Association said its 2,000 UPS pilots would refuse work in the event of a strike.
Murray said the company would do all it could to ensure that hospital supplies, blood supplies and packages containing other critical supplies reached their destinations.
"We have many contingency plans," he said.
Federal mediator John Calhoun Wells said the strike would affect hundreds of thousands of workers and millions of UPS customers and affect the overall U.S. economy.

"We didn't succeed, that's deeply disappointing," said Wells, who directs the Federal Mediation and Conciliation Service. "They were far enough apart so that we were unable to bridge the gap this evening," he said.
UPS Chairman James Kelly and his negotiating team arrived about an hour before the union on Sunday to meet with the mediator and consider a new union proposal, but the talks stalled.
The White House has been keeping close tabs on the negotiations, but spokesman Barry Toiv said President Bill Clinton did not plan to intervene at this time.

"At this time, the administration does not believe that the standard for intervention under the Taft-Hartley Act has been met," Toiv said, referring to a federal law that has not been used for decades.
Carey said the union was particularly concerned about preventing work going to subcontractors rather than union workers, the pension plan, and health and safety issues.
UPS said last week that the threat of a strike was costing it about $5 million a day in business lost to competitors such as the Postal Service and Federal Express Corp.
The Postal Service said it will limit the number of parcels customers can mail at a single time and take other steps to handle an expected increase in volume.
UPS spokeswoman Gina Ellrich said the carrier's daily shipping volume was already down by 1 million packages from 12 million, forcing it to lay off several thousand workers.

In its contract offer, UPS offered to boost pay for both full- and part-time workers by $1.50 to $2.50 per hour over five years. Under the company proposal, a profit-sharing plan would provide a first payment of $3,060 to full-time employees and $1,530 to part-time workers in 1997.
With revenue of $22.4 billion in 1996, UPS annually handles about 3 billion parcels and documents, shipped to more than 200 countries from 1,700 hubs and centres.
